content.description:
A dinner invitation

1 Cenabis bene, mi Fabulle, apud me

paucis, si tibi di favent, diebus,

si tecum attulerisaffero, afferre, attuli: to bring bonam atque magnam

cenam, non sine candida puella

5 et vino et salesal, salis, n.: salt; [figuratively] wit et omnibus cachinnis.cachinnus, -i, m.: a loud laugh

haec si, inquam, attuleris, venustevenustus, -a, -um: charming noster

cenabis bene; nam tui Catulli

plenus sacculussacculus, -i, m.: a purse est aranearum.aranea, -ae, f.: cobweb

sed contra accipies merosmerus, -a, -um: pure, unmixed amores

10 seu quid suavius elegantiusve est:

nam unguentumunguentum, -i n.: perfume dabo, quod meae puellae

donarunt Veneres Cupidinesque,

quod tu cum olfacies,olfacio, olfacere: to smell deos rogabis

totum ut te faciant, Fabulle, nasum.
content.question: In Roman practice, cena, or dinner, was served in the

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 2.B: Describe historical and cultural contexts of Latin texts.
